reviewText: Not a comprehensive but poignant view of a superstar's life. Full songs should have been included. A star that no  longer shines.
I love Whitney but this is tabloid trash. That's all I can say about it. Don't waste your time on this documentary.

This movie is put together well. It really is just a documentary that put together all the stories of her carried in the media plus interviews. Ignore the two fanboys who poorly rated it. I suppose cause this show talks about the REAL Whitney, not the Whitney everybody demanded, which drove her to drugs.

A sad story of one of the best singers all time. Covers her rise to fame and downfall. Shows a sad side to fame and how difficult it is to pretend to be someone your not. It pulls no punches with the truth. Even though raised in middle class Whitney has famous relatives and way too much expected of her from birth. As a young girl, prior to fame, she began a long hard road of drug usage that ultimately ended her life too young.

I recommend this movie to anyone who wishes to see all the media stories all in one place, including news coverage.
The video was great and so was the quality. I learned things I never knew about Whitney. I will watch it again.
Just absolutely terrible.  Do yourself a favor, don't purchase.  Not anything like I'd thought it be.  I got suckered!  This DVD should recieve a zero star.

If you're a frequent viewer of Whitney-fan.com's message board, you'll likely recognize my username as the co-moderator of the forum.

When this DVD was ORIGINALLY planned, its description touted unreleased footage and rare interviews with Whitney.  When I got it, it was anything but.  The DVD cover art was XEROXED and the DVD itself was a regular DVD-R with a HQ printer label on it.  Moreover, they used stock Google images photos of Whitney (the whole 4 they used).  Otherwise, there were a bunch of random "fans" (I use the term lightly) giving their take on Whitney Houston and their favorite songs of hers--outside, on their couches, behind their computers, on campus.  It looks as if it was recorded on a HQ cell phone camera or a handheld camera.  NOTHING about this is professional.  Heck, they showed NO footage of Whitney, barely showed pics, BARELY heard her music.

LEARN your Whitney Houston history if you're gonna try to release something like this.  Whitney-fan.com and ClassicWhitney.com would be places to start.

I've had the DVD one day and it's going BACK for a full refund.

If this is the way you show your love to Whitney, I'd damn sure hate to see how you show your hate to her!  I wish I could give this 0 out of 5 stars.
Great!
ok

Great documentary!  We will always love you, Whitney!

They've got a couple media people doing most of the commentary; it really colors it poorly.  I'd rather hear the stories from friends or other musicians, not from people who made a living being a part of the paparazzi machine that drives a lot of artists to drugs.  FYI, these same two clowns do an Amy Winehouse documentary that i couldn't even get through because of the oily feeling they give me.
Reminded me of a time in my life when things were simple....eventually I got the experience to know part of her struggle. I wish it would have focused more on the music then the addiction.
Interesting perspective.  I expected more video clips of performances.  This was more a chronicle of perceptions on Whitney and her life than a biography.
Excellent bio, but doesn't say much about abuse and family life.  Movie tries not to dwell on the negative elements in her life. What a great woman in spite of her drug addiction.
Enjoyed

personally, I found it to be a waste of my time.  some people who i am not familiar with running their lips about what the world already new. there was nothing contained therein of any substance.
A very well done myopic view of an extraordinary  star. It follows her ascent to her unfortunate early demise.
Good

Beautiful, I truly miss her voice.  Such a terrible waste of talent!  Altho i loved all her recordings I think my all time favorite of her was her rendition of the Star Spangled Banner at the Super Bowl!  It was spectacular!
Very interesting documentary especially if your a Whitney Houston fan
Nice documentary about Whitney Houston from the perspective of those outside the music business.

This documentary helped me renew my respect for Whitney Houston, by helping me understand her addiction. Bless her for being of such service to humanity, using her gift to bring emotional releases for many that needed it while listening to her music.  Perhaps she helped others overcome their own addictions (by having her music to listen and turn to) to ease emotional pain.  As a retired professional singer myself, I know the dangers of the entertainment field.  Although I was able to gain "my high" through simply singing and playing musical instruments, others are not that fortunate.  Incredible amounts of fame obviously took its toll on her.
God but tragic
Very entertaining if you love her music!

This was very well done, and I enjoyed it.  I always loved her voice, and found it very sad that she got into the drug scene, which led eventually to her death.

Nice and fairly thorough review of her accomplished but sad life. It should be a warning to those who party a little too hardy.  You don't know what you've got til it's gone.

Over-rated sycophantic crud.  No songs are played to any length, and we pretty much only get froth from people who actually believe they are "experts" on the subject.  Superficial, showbiz clips with no depth whatsoever.
Great movie!
Rejoice - She's singing with all the angels and saints, but surely missed down here!

I wonder how a human being can have such an immense, powerful, profound gift that is without a doubt from the highest realm of spirit - of God - I wonder how a human being can be so close to her divine soul - and to be able to emanate her truest self from God - can be so troubled. I know that how she lived her life - all the way to the end - I know for sure that that was the path she, her highest self - her soul had chosen to walk. She had lessons she needed to learn - and I hope she learned them - But she also had a purpose. I feel that she had a purpose to deliver a message from God and spirit. And how she would deliver that message here on earth was going to be through her voice. Listening to Whitney Houston calls all of me to look at my deeper self - to my divine self - my higher self - to my God given soul self. Her voice pulls people into their own hearts - into their own SOUL.  She came to fulfill a purpose. And I feel she did.
No new information here other then a wonderful reminder of the talent we lost too soon.

As someone who has followed Whitney for most of her career, I found this documentary one part inspiring, one part tragedy, and one part in-depth reporting. I learned a lot of things I didn't know about her, but it was also a bitter reminder of her sad and untimely end. I recommend watching it.

I enjoyed it hearing about how she rose to stardom, I didn't like the last song she sang when her voice was apparently gone. I would consider it to anyone who I know loved Whitney as I did when she was herself. I know it's Hollywood and that's the way they do things there, but I don't see how they could leave her body up there while business as usual took place right down stairs.
In depth look at Whitney Houston's life. This is a very interesting documentary that all will enjoy and be saddened by
Great movie

this covered more of her life than I expected, raising questions, but not answering all of them. Loved her a lot, so her crash still feels like such a loss for all of us. I forgot how young she was when she first hit the spotlight. Probably still the best rendering of our national anthem ever, though (surprising to me)Lady Gaga came close at last Super Bowl.
goodbye I think it's missing more details

Worth a watch if you're a Whitney fan like me, but could have been better.  Those making comments were the same throughout the show and seemed a little over the top.  Couldn't believe they didn't emphasize the birth of Bobbi Kristina...she's mentioned but only briefly, and not a significant part of the overall timeline which would have made much more sense.
